Deep, rich hop bomb. Citrus, floral and real resinous. You get the entire spectrum of bitterness. Malt is here but takes a backseat to hops. Oily texture with a medium body. Anything else I type would be rambling. Bottom line, another top tier brew from the Hill.

Had served in my HF stemmed glass at Harvest in around @ 1 pm. It was kicked within an hour. Pours straw golden with an appealing sudsy, bulbous eggshell white head two-to-three fingers in length. First off, this is a grass bomb: nosed grass trimmings, possibly the strongest and most realistic on the nose Ive yet encountered in a beer; tilled soil, gruit herbs, flowers, grist, honey and seaweed. Tastes predominately of freshly cut wet spring grass, edamame, sunflower seeds, Simcoe hops and clementine. Ends yeasty with notes of sweat, dried pineapple, and some fir bark. Simply jaw-dropping
Growler sample.  Straw with no head.  Floral hop aroma, quite sweet and floral flavor.  Good IPA but nothing amazing.

(Growler) cloudy amber-orange that glows, lasting creamy eggshell white head with nice lacing on the glass. Nose of orange marmalade, fresh grapefruit juice, lightly spicy peppercorn and rye, fragrant, aggressive and about as complex as a DIPA gets. Candi sugar, floral, sweaty stone fruit as it warms. Really locin the smell as it warms. Taste is quite spicy too, probably alcohol but comes across as rye, citrus rind without being bitter, orange marmalade, and lots more. Very carbonated, medium body, refreshing, bitter, well balanced, fragrant, citrusy. Complex and awesome. Shaun can do no wrong it seems.

Growler shared at Sanders place, NYC on an evening where we drank way too much beer - but a lot of it was HF, so it was good. This beer pours a lightly cloudy, rich gold with a frothy white head. Tons of sweet-smelling, juicy orange in the aroma. Big sweet flavor with honey and pale malts, hints of alcohol, grapefruit, orange, papaya. Full bodied with fine, smooth carbonation. Super sticky, resinous finish with lots of juicy pine, ripe citrus, big pectin, honey, fructose, tons of tropical fruits. This drinks like a dream. Delicious.

750ml swing top growler.  Pour hazy orange with a huge head.  Taste mildly of oranges, floral, and a big piney finish.  Pretty good, but carries  a liittle weird watery taste too, must be the well water.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2013 750mL Growler, purchased at the Brewery. Pugnacious, punching hop sick aroma. Overwhelmed with green-yellow lupulin insanity. Hawaiian punch and passionfruit. What lies beneath the waft feels like hop heaven settled in a glass and laiden with the right amount of sugar. Crystalline malt played against every tropical fruit polyphenol flavor you could imagine. Pineapples and sex. Its green with hop gold. Bitterness is balanced well with the bright prickly bitterness and drizzled over with honey. Beautiful. Hill Farmsteads hoppy beers rock me like none other.
growler and tap from hill. pours hazy light orange with beautiful head. big pine and grapefruit aroma. taste is semi sweet medium body creamy and mango yummmmm

Growler @ Stephens house. Thanks so much! Cloudy/milky yellow orange appearance with a khaki head. Onion/garlic, piney, ganja, mild grapefruit citrusy, fairly spicy hoppy aroma. Delicious, grapefruit/orange citrusy, garlic, piney, marijuana, chewy earthy, tasty flavor. Really a nice IIPA.

Growler at home with friends. Poured a golden orange in appearance with a small white head and good lacing. Aroma is super dank, weed, resin, grass, and grapefruit peel. Taste is big pine, spruce needles, resin, grass, bitter grapefruit peel, and weed, yet well-balanced and easy to drink. Medium mouthfeel with soft carbonation. Really easy to drink, yet very complex with big flavors and just an all-around solid DIPA. Nice!

Pours a very hazy deep yellow almost orange body with a thin white head. Aroma is dominated by the hops. Aroma is of a vibrant citrus and piney profile. Taste is well balanced with the aroma but is lost initially as the hops are that dominating. Flavors linger but without an overpowering bitter flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Whenever Im away from Greensboro, the suspicion looms that my favorite beer of all time is benefiting from its associatiions with Greensboro. I just tasted it again for perhaps the tenth time. It is clearly superior to any other brew Ive ever tasted anywhere!!
On draft at Cigar City, pours a cloudy dark orange color aromas of fresh citrus and peaches, with hops thrown in.  Flavors are the same with a nice amout of bitterness in the aftertaste.

Hazy orange in colour with a thin white head, good lacing.  The aroma is very floral, very hoppy, lots of grapefruit, peaches, pineapple, quite tropical really.  The flavour is of pineapple and peaches, some oranges and grapefruit, resinous, some caramel, lots of hops.  Bitter mouthfeel, medium body, moderate carbonation.  Finishes long, fruity and hoppy.
Just incredible.  Easily one of the best aromas and my new favorite DIPA.  Dangerously drinkable.
Draught at Dieu du Ciel 13th Anniversary Party on September 17, 2011.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2012 Growler shared by drabmuh. Thanks Matt!

The beer is yellowish to orange in color, and mildly hazy. The head is a finger or so thick and leaves a healthy amount of lacing upon the glass. The aroma...ah. Wonderful. A barrage of tropical citrus fruits, most notably mango, pineapple, and orange, fill the olfactory senses with a hop lovers dream come true. While the flavor doesnt quite live up to the expectations delivered by the superb aroma, this beer is delicious nonetheless. Remarkably drinkable and wonderfully smooth on the palate. Highly recommended.

I smell peaches! Looks great in a snifter, then BOOM! the hops hit you. Wonderful citrusy, piney taste. Reminds me of Bells Hop Slam, and thats a compliment! I cant really comment on the malt because Im too wrapped up on the hops. First time, but definitely not last time!

Pours a hazy gold with a paperthin head. Aroma dominated by hops. Bitter and dry. So good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

from philly beer week, on tap, pours slightly cloudy orangish with a nice white head, nose is intensely pine, resinous and citrus. mostly pine. kinda catty. taste is as resinous as smell but it is deceptively drinkable. There arent many times when I can say I can drink  a 2x IPA all day. I could drink this all day.

Growler. Pour is deep gold, small white head, decent retention/lace. Aroma of grapefruit, floral hops, light caramel. Taste is bitter; orange/tropical hops, cracker, light sweetness. Palate is soft, slightly sticky, bitter finish.

Big thanks to yobdoog for this one! Hazy orange pour with a small film of a head. Cant believe how hazy it is. Nose is mild pines, flowers, citrus, perfume, ripe oranges, and other resinous complexities. Little to no malt aroma to speak of. Flavor is again orange and sweet citrus and some sweet malts that quickly dries out on the palate in the finish. medium body and drinkable. Quite the drinkable hoppy beer. Nice.

On tap at Boilermaker.  Poured a cloudy light amber with orange hues, a thick white head, and significant lacing.  Aroma is clear citrus, mainly orange peel and papaya, piney resin, and caramel malt.  Taste is very well balanced blend of piney hop bitterness, citrus notes, and palatable malt sweetness.  Significant mouthfeel and flavors linger on the palate long after the last sip.

growler from second anniversary party. pours a nice golden orange with a full but delicate head. smells of oranges apricots and pine. a tasty treat to boot with a nice floral citrus pop balanced well with ample but not overpowering bitterness. could probably have a few of these bad boys before the DIPA fatigue sets in....

On draft at brewery. Pours a hazy orange with a large white head. Huge citrus aromas with some floral notes. This beer is brewed so well. Hints of sweetness from the caramel malts that finish dry and clean. Amazing thank god I was able to have 3. :)

750 ml growler from lushawn- thanks again, Shawn! Pours a hazy golden orange color with a small eggshell white head. Aroma of herbal, citrusy hops, pineapple, papaya, caramel malts, and pine. Flavor of tangerine citrus, pineapple, melon, caramel malts, pine resin, and floral notes. Medium-bodied, with a bitter, resinous, and juicy mouthfeel and low carbonation. Very nice DIPA.

Growler from David - thanks!  Pours a hazy but vibrant glowing orange and yellow with a slick of white foam.  Aroma is resinous pine with spots of citrus and mango over a complimentary bitterness and a dry, clean malt backbone that only shows the slightest bit of sweetness on the tail end of the finish.  Taste is a melange of resinous pine, touches of citrus, balancing hop bitterness, and a whisp of malt sweetness on the finish.  Clean, slightly coating mouthfeel.  Exceptionally well made and scarily drinkable.

My weekend of delicious hoppy Hill Farmstead stuff continues.  Flip-top growler from joeybones3.  Big tropical fruit nose; even more than Society and Solitude #3 had, whiffs of mango, papaya, orange peel, and even some lemon.  Quite herbal with also a touch of grass.  The color is a hazy rusty gold with a thin off-white head settling on top.  This is a very clean hoppy Double IPA.  Its floral, herbal, with some light sweet malt, and very tropical tasting; pineapple, mango, grapefruit, and a touch of coconut make for a very tasty hop bomb.  The bitterness is assertive but far from abrasive.  Some sticky alcohol heat does show in the finish but that comes with making an 8% hoppy beer.  Its really quite refreshing and easy to drink.  Yum.

From a 750 ML bottle poured at the brewery. Hazy amber appearance. Smells of citrus and pine. Sweet grapefruit flavor with a great hoppy dryness to finish things off. Such an excellent beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2014 Directement dun growler: Sa robe orange trouble est surmonté dune spectaculaire tête crémeuse. Bouquet extrêmement complet qui laisse présager un liquide mâchable. Des notes de résine de pin, de pêche, dorange accompagne à merveille le côté plus végétal, floral.  Son corps est pulpeux, lamertume est élégante, magnifique bière.

Pretty sexy package on this one. Really fruity body. Hard to say if its better  than the Heady Topper I had right after but it may just be. Strong hops but not overdone. Just a great package with attention on all the details. On tap at Farmhouse Tap and Grill.

Served in a goblet at Canal St, Reading.

Pours a cloudy, glowing peachy amber with a thick creamy white head. Average retention and abundant streaks of sticky lacing. 

Aroma is a little disappointing. Abundant resin and citrus hops dominate; more sweet than bitter. Pleasant, but a little one dimensional.

Body is thicker side of medium, chewy and smooth with strong carbonation. Flavor adds more complexity than the nose with a mild peach sweetness on the front of the palate with grapefruit and citrus resiny bitterness on the back. Throughout there is a light lemon rind, grass and strong bready malt flavors balancing the hops. At colder temperatures this reminded me of something like Ruination, but as this warmed it turned into a unique beast of an IIPA. This was maltier than some other hop bomb IIPAs; combined with the lower alcohol and unique peach flavors this is highly drinkable and recommended.

Pours a hazy golden color with an eggshell head.  Aroma is heavy dank hops, resin and some mint?  Taste is sweet malts with some tropical notes and some green (unripe) mangoes.  Medium bodied with a dry finish.  Good.

Pours up deep gold with a thin copper core and supporting an off white head. The aroma offers up thick chewy resiny hop goodness in the form of spicy yummy hops, bitter floral hops and then a resiny near grassy note in the background. The taste is pleasingly similar with rich sticky near resiny spicy and floral hops sliding around effortlessly over the top of a thin sheet of sweet malts. Yes. The hops offer up deep rich hop bitterness as well as ample amounts of late addition to the boil hoppy flavor goodness. Nice stuff.

A hazed golden ale with a super thick lacing golden white head. In aroma, superb balanced and creamy floral hops, flowers, beautiful. In mouth, a smooth floral hops, nice and restrained, white grapefruits, resinous, pungent and well balanced. On tap at the brewery, March 12, 2012.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2012 Growler to snifter at Jackie Os the night before the bottle release. Looks good; light and lively. Smells great; grassy and hoppy. Tastes good; a lighter DIPA with a great flavor profile. Mouthfeel is good too. Overall, a tasty beer that I hope to have again.

Thanks to mikey for the growler, split with friends for our UFC tasting. 

A - Pours a hazy orangish/red, a fingers-worth of off-white head, spotty lacing, and a thin cap.

S - Nice citrus aroma, lots of hops, some fruity/floral notes in there as well. Lots of citrus, grapefruit, floral hops, nice bitterness on the nostrils.

T - Lots of hops...citrus/floral/herbal, big juicy grapefruit and pine notes. Bitter, bitter, and some more bitter. You like hops? Youll enjoy this DIPA.

M - Light to medium, soft carbonation, oily finish.

D - I think Ephraim in the better DIPA, but this one is very solid. Very easy to drink, as I had a couple of glasses. Recommend!

Holy crap these guys rock.  Man oh man.  Pours a wonderfully orangish color, nice and cloudy, great head retention.  Such a fresh, pungeant hop aroma.  Grassy, resinous, citrus peel.  Flavor just melts in your mouth after the spicy, juicy hops attack your tastebuds.  This is freaking delicious.

From notes.  First reviewed 9/28/2011.  Poured from a 64 oz. growler into a tulip. Thanks to idrinkgas for sending this over.

Out of the growler, my pour has a nice creamy froth of a white head above a cloudy tangerine beer. Pretty nice retention from a growler.

Some lightly sweet crackery malt wafts into my nose first, but the aroma is full of hops. Floral, some grassy, lots of grapefruit, and a bit of spicy pine. Very nice.

A good amount of biscuity malt does its best to stand up to the hops, but fairly quickly the tidal wave of hops wins. A balanced hop presence - grapefruit citrus, some grass, and some prickly pine. The finish is fairly clean.

Abner has a balanced full body, a little bit of booze. Smooth, creamy carbonation. Lightly grainy, not much hop oil left on the tongue after each sip.

This is a well made, balanced, hop bomb. Very good, I have no qualms about finishing a decent portion of this growler.

review date: 3/4/12

poured from growler into a Sam Adams glass

Nose: strong floral hops with a bit of sweet alcohol
Appearance: Thin head that dissapates quicky, beautiful cloudy golden in color
Taste: I can find nothing wrong with this beer.  Potent hoppy grapefruit with a very nice, lasting, slightly bitter finish.  No floral or sweet notes as I noticed in the smell, but just perfect.  Finished the 750ml growler over a three day period and found it more pleasurable with each pour.  On day 2 and 3 I had it in a Hill Farmstead stemmed glass, and I think that made it even better as the aromas came out a bit more.

One last note, on day three I followed my last Abner with my 2nd-ever Heddy Topper.  Both beers weigh in at 8%+ APV with no inidication of being this strong, and both are wonderful, but for my money, Abner wins this head-to-head Vermont competition :)

Seriously growler side by side with several big IPAs and some boring stouts. Thanks to Mike, Mike, Ben, Jeff, and me for making this whole thing happen. Very awesome afternoon.

Beer is mildly hazy, orangish in color and has a wispy head that leaves some lacing, carbonation moderate to low.

Aroma is nice and piny with a little citrus in there as well, no malt. So far so good.

I like this beer too. Thinner than Kryptonite but not watery, the bitterness is spot on, no malt up front with a nice palate of great great pine, earth and citrus hops. Most drinkable out fo the bunch for sure.

Serving type: growler

Growler pour, from Mr. Dany Labrie, with some serious thanks due to Scott as well. Pours hazy gold; thin white head, spotty lacing. Nose is spicy and grassy with some and bubblegum. Nose is markedly lifted, present even 4 inches from the mouth of the glass, presenting tropical fruit from a remarkable distance away. Flavours of Juicy Fruit gum, loads of navel orange, grapefruit, and nectarines. This is some skilful hop blending on display right here, folks!
Pretty nice DIPA. Pours a nice golden color. Aromas are really nice on this one with a bunch of grapefruit and onions. Tatse is somewhat of a let down but still a damn solid beer.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2012 Split a growler with some buddies. Poured a light orange/dark yellow color with a bubbly white head - for being a week or two old from the brewery, it?s held up well. Aroma was mango/ripe peaches, with a touch of resin. Fresh, fresh, fresh smell. The flavor isn?t quite as good - but it may have fallen off a bit. Notes of grass, pine hops, pretty good malt balance.
Growler shared by sajaad. Aroma is sweet tropical fruit and pineapple. Taste is vert balanced between malt hops and sweetness.

Growler sample via oakbluff. Consumed with Savvy1982 and oakbluff. Pale gold in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of orange peel, weed, tangerine, kumquat, and pale malt. Hop forward in the mouth as well, with loads of grassy, tropical, and citrus fruit notes. Only a faint amount of pale malt in the background for balance. Firm bitterness, and moderate body. One heck of a hop delivery vehicle.
wow, good stuff, pour is hazy yellow, aroma is very citursy lots of life, very hoppy and just a solid beer, tastes very similar to heady topper

Med/large fluffy white head with excellent retention and plenty of droopy lacing. Fairly murky, copper orange color. Large hop nose, grapefruit and tropical notes all over the place. Lil pissy, resiny. Body is med/full, chewy and juicy, lil acidic with a soft carbonation, nicely oily, mouthwatering. Plenty of juicy hop flavors, mainly grapefruit, peaches, oranges with a little sweet maltiness not balancing out the hop bill, lil earth, leaf. Lots goin on. Fairly dry, fruity finish, good strong bitterness that lasts. Ya want more! ABV is just right. Awesome beer, as expected. Serious thanks to Gorgar for hookin a brutha up! Immensely enjoyed from a week old 750 swing top growler fill. The murkiness cost it a point or two.

As soon I popped the top on this growler I was attacked with a huge hoppy presence.  Grapefruit is huge!  Citrus isnt lagging far behind and a piney aroma brings up the rear.  I could of sat there all night long just taking in the aroma of this beer.  Amazing!

Now a lot of the time iyoull hear me say something like The taste doesnt match the aroma  Not here.  I think the taste is actually better than the aroma.  The hop profile here isnt clean.  Instead its a deep hop aroma.  Its hard to explain other than say its a dank and dirty and its just over the top fantastic.  Huge amount of grapefruit, citrus, and pine.  It just sits there, lingers  There seems to be some other tropical fruits mixed in there but the grapefruit and citrus take frontstage and run away with the show.  You can tell this beer is dry hopped big time.  It just sits in the mouth.  Theres a slight bitterness to it that comes in about half way and lingers just a tad on the aftertaste.  Everything about this beer just worked for me.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, chewy, and leaves a bit of a dryness on the palette.

Pours a hazy honey/orange color with a medium whige head...nice lacing.  Aroma has grapefruit, peach, mango, and nice mild piney notes.  Flavor follows suit...great distinctive citrus and stonefruit flavors...just a bit more pine than the aroma suggests...perfect bitterness.  Mouthfeel is medium and the finish is piney/bitter and dry...lingers nicely.  Wow!  More please.
Draft. Pours orange with a puffy white head. Smells very piney with some citrus. Taste is medium bitter. Really good.

Had this at Three Penny Taproom on draft. $7 USD for a pour into a HFS glass. The drunk guy next to me said, "good choice, bro!"


A - Light yellow appearance with lots of resin haze. Great alcohol legs on the edge of the glass. No head to speak of.

S - Dry hops, citrus, great woodiness like birch and some cinnamon.

T - Grapefruit is HUGE with pine, resin and orange peels. Theres a spiciness to this beer that I cant quite pinpoint.

M - All bubbles, tons of lingering aftertaste for a delicious beer. Medium bodied.

O - Amazing beer. Maybe one of the best Double IPAs Ive EVER had.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2013 Re-rate. A: Hazy, wheat-orange body. Large off-white head that stuck around for a bit.

S: assertive blend of pine, grapefruit, and orange. 

T: Mostly citric notes of orange and grapefruit. Moderate amounts of soft floral resinous and pine notes in the background.

M: Medium to light body. Assertive carbonation. Refreshing finish.

O: quite nice

Served on-tap at Capones during the Hill Farmstead party during Philly Beer Week. I missed this one last time, glad I finally got to try it.

A - Pours hazy orange with a small half finger tall white head leaving small wisps of lacing down the glass.

S - Smells of citric hops, grapefruit, pine, bready malt, and a touch of caramel sweetness. The nose was good but when you have a Double Citra sitting right beside it there really isnt much of a comparison. Still very nice tho.

T - Starts off with a nice grapefruit kick quickly giving way to a mix of light citric hops, caramel sweetness and some dry chewiness. Very nice overall balance throughout. Finish is a touch dry with some lingering hop bitterness. Pretty good but not as good as the other hoppy HF beers.

M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Slick, chewy, feel with plenty of lingering hop bitterness in the finish.

O - I enjoyed this one quite a bit but when you compare it to the other hoppy Hill Farmstead beers it is clearly fourth or fifth best. Not knocking it one bit as it is still an awesome beer, just not as good as some of the other HF hoppy beers.

(Draught)  Pours a cloudy orange body with a medium white head.  Aroma of earth, weed, peach, and citrus.  Flavor of citrus, pineapple, earth, and grass with a dry, lingering bitter finish.  Another great beer from Hill Farmstead.

Poured into a snifter. Thanks to CharlieMurphy for this.

4.0 A: Opaque medium orange color. Just under two fingers of creamy white head. Retention is about average and a small ring of lacing is left.

4.5 S: Nose on this is wonderful! Tons of tropical fruits. Mango, pineapple, papaya, and orange in descending order. Grapefruit and pine to a lesser extent. Despite the haziness, there is little in terms of yeast and is super clean overall. Malts are negligible save for a touch of neutral sweetness.

4.5 T: Taste is as good as the nose. There are a lot of DIPAs that are jampacked with fruitiness in the nose that doesnt also occupy the taste, but this isnt one of them. Ample amounts of mango, orange, and pineapple. A little less papaya. The grapefruit and pine are much more pronounced. Again, some balancing neutral malt sweetness and surpringly clean. Bitterness starts out quite soft, but progresses to mild-moderate halfway into the glass.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Moderately creamy. Good here.

4.5 D: Hill Farmstead has to be one of the best breweries in the world. Everything they make is great. After having another killer DIPA, its safe to say that theres no question that they know what to do with hops. Solid brew all around.

Serving type: growler

Reviewed on: 10-30-2011 05:32:32

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 growler. pours a hazed dark orange with a frothy offwhite head. aroma of big juicy tropical fruits, grapefruit, freshly sliced oranges, and a touch of pineapple. sharp, bitter red grapefruit. hop forward, but a lightly toasted crisp caramel malt backing provides some balance. a peculiar sharp bitter herbal resin booze note makes this less than ideal for sessioning.  however, it is quite a nice beer.

Sampled from a 750 ml. Growler sent out thanks to Robert. Nice gold orange like color. Aromas were luscious of tropical fruit and citrus. mouthfeel smooth and a tad resiny and dank. Flavors were well balanced of orange, mango , lemon, and grapefruit. Solid hop bitterness but melded perfectly with the malt. Finish is long lasting and alcohol very hidden. Fantastic!

Courtesy of fbm115. dark golden, oily, minimal head. Aroma dominated by grapefruit and pine resin, light malt backbone. Well balanced throughout flavor, dig that its not loaded with crystal malts, but still a tad cloying for me. Sticky mouthfeel. Nice IIPA, solid, just not my thing anymore.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 Pours hazy gold with a thin white head that leaves a little lacing. Aroma is citrusy, almost juicy hops. Mouthfeel is medium-full. Flavor is intense citrusy hops, but very smooth. No harshness at all. Very nice

Courtesy of fbm115
The aroma consists of oranges, grapefruit, peach, and tropical fruits.  It pours a slightly hazy amber with a small white head that leaves behind some spotty lacing.  The flavor starts with lots of citrus with oranges, tropical fruits, and a touch lemon.  The finish has mild grapefruit.  Medium bodied with mild carbonation and a soft mouthfeel.  Overall, a very "sessionable" IIPA.
Growler muled by oteyj, thanks.  Cloudy golden color, huge fluffy white head.  Aroma of grass, fruit, perfume.  Taste starts with bread and finishes bitter.  Decent.
On draft.  Orange color with a nice white head.  Citrusy and fruity aroma as well taste.  Nice bitterness make this a nice refreshing drinkable pale ale.

beautiful hazy apricot color, creamy off-white head.  aromas of citrus, tropical fruit, great mineral components, and some grassy earth.  tastes of smooth caramel malts, incredible hop balance, citrus, and tropical fruits.

Draft at union jacks.  Nice golden/peachy pour with a small white head.  Aroma was very tropical ( mango, peach and pineapple).  There were some floral and citrus notes hiding behind the fruit.  The flavor was very tropical as well, nicely balanced by bitterness.  I would have liked a touch more citrus in the flavor.  Medium body with perfect carbonation.  This was a very good IIPA.  It tasted like a scaled down version of Ephraim with a little less citrus.

750ml growler via Zane.  I was fully expecting this to be a let down from Ephraim that was consumed right before this.  Not at all.  Aroma is all mango. Seriously, mango beyond belief.  Slightly less orange than Ephraim.  Taste, outstanding! More mango and tropical fruit. Bitterness but nothing crazy.  A DIPA I could drink all day.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Pours a golden tan color with some head that leaves sticky lacing. Nose is strong notes of peaches, mango and papaya. Unreal! First sip is strong with citrus. Finish is bitter with light grapefruit.  Awesome!

Tasted at the harvest festival multiple times.  This one is a wonderfully easy drinking version of ephraim.  The flavors are the same with heavy citrus notes but everything is a little less bold.  The overall flavor profile is nearly identical though.  Great work.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2014 Smells just like the Ephraim. A little lighter and easy drinker. Another laser show!

On Tap at Issacs.

WOW!  Orange/ Hazed pour. with a bold citrus, floral , hoppy pine aroma.

A perfect blend of Citrus fruit, orange peel, hop, caramel and sweet malts.

Absolutely stunning.

On tap at Hawthornes in Philly. This was really good but I liked the Amarillo APA a bit better. This pours a light amber, closer to orange with a small head. The aroma is very nice with a lot of citrus along with some sweet malt. The flavor starts with the malt and then gets nice and hoppy. A very crisp and dry finish. Very good.

On tap at Station Taproom in Downingtown, hands down the best Abner of the 6 or so times I have had it this year! The brew pours thick orange honey in color with an off white head. The aroma is light hoppy grapefruit. The flavors of sweet and juicy grapefruit come through with an excellent blend of light bitter and sweet hop notes. No bite at all here, so smooth going down on a medium to thick body that complements the flavors so well.

Verres, dun fût chez Dieu du Ciel ! Arômes explosifs de houblons américains, fruités et résineux. Robe orangée et trouble, effervescence très souple et belle mousse qui tient bien. En bouche, les houblons sont évidemment à lavant-plan, faisant preuve dune très belle complexité fruitée et résineuse. Malgré le caractère explosif du houblonnage, le malt se démarque également par de délicates notes biscuitées. La texture en bouche de cette bière est particulièrement réussie, très souple et veloutée. Finale bien sèche présentant une amertume dintensité moyenne. Lalcool est absolument invisible. Du grand art et le summum de la double IPA !

Une pinte du fût au Dieu du Ciel 13ème anniversaire / Zwanze 2011. Belle bière blonde-jaune trouble. La mousse est compacte et épaisse. Au nez cette bière offre des effluves de citron, dagrumes, de conifère, de houblons frais, dépinette. Rarement une bière était aussi odorante. La bouche se rapproche de la perfection, un équilibre exemplaire entre le houblon et le malt. 9/10

Drank on tap (8 oz) at Dieu du Ciels 13th anniversary party/ Zwanze Day in Montreal, on September 17, 2011. Muddy honey yellow, thin head. Dry hop aroma, sweet spice. Taste of citrus hops ultra dry, sweet notes of grapefruit, good dry bitterness. Abner is a good guy!

Pale golden orange pour thin white head light striped lacing .... aroma is of pine and citrusy hops ..... taste is of grapefruit, pine and lots of citrusy hops dry and lightly bitter with a nice hop zing ... citrusy and tasty brew with a little biscuity malty backbone ...  finishes dry with a lingering hop bitterness

(Zwanze Day 2011, Dieu du Ciel 13th anniversary)  Un anneau de mousse flotte sur un liquide à la robe orangée et embrouillée.  Le nez est explosif, un bombardement de fruits tropicaux : la mangue est bien mûre, lananas fraîchement coupé et le pamplemousse légèrement sucré.  Des parfums floraux chatouillent les narines tandis que des effluves de pin sexpriment avec une certaine force.  La base maltée est bien présente : des notes grillées se choquent à des arômes de miel et de sucre blanc.  Les saveurs sont spectaculaires : bien houblonnées et aromatiques, jamais trop intenses en amertume.  Les malts sont doux, justement dosés, prêts à jouer les seconds violons : on oublie presque leur présence tellement le travail des houblons est merveilleux.  La sensation en bouche est très belle : le corps est dense, le pétillement très doux et la texture moelleuse.  La finale se fait sur de longues notes houblonnées, très parfumées et jamais trop agressives.   This is truly an amazing brew.  Packed with a lot of flavors.  What is the name of that guy  again?  Shaun?  Man, this dude is a serious wizard!

On tap at DDC 13th aniv party. 
Aroma fresh, crisp , resin , flowery hop character, hibiscus, rose, grapefruit with sweet enough fill to be balanced heavy dose of hops. 8+
 Appearance  hazed amber , creamy mid plus top. Thick lace on walls.
Flavor and Palate : Soft bodied. Green leafy bitterness yet none of harshness. This was made to be so approachable yet its bold, big full of hops heavyweight. Then you look on reverse and you might even call this delicate and balanced. Superb brewing work!

Growler Hazy orange ale with a small, pillowy, off-white head. Decent retention. The nose presents a fruity, earthy medley of peach, grapefruit, caramel and tea biscuit bonded by slighter, more ambiguous notes of musk and cat piss. Medium-bodied with a relatively thin mouthfeel and soft carbonation.  The hoppy flavor is bitter, but even more savory  fruity peach and grapefruit layered atop cereal grains, earthiness and pine. Crisp, medium bitter, dry finish with lingering fruitiness. Growler courtesy of the ever-generous Maltzilla!

on tap at reservoir, waterbury. clear golden with a nice white head, excellent retention and lacing. tons of malts, toasted malts, honey. lots of floral hops - medium hopping, with a nice tingling, peppery and gentle grapefruit bite at the end. soft to average carbonation, medium body, honey-syrupy body. great again hf!
Pours nice and golden.  Flavor and taste is a huge burst of citrus with grassy undertones.  Hints of pine sweetness creeps in as well.  World class brew.

Another delicious brew provided by maltzilla. Poured out of growler into snifter. Tons of hoppy citrus aroma. Flavor was earthy and piney with a nice malt backing. Slight grapefruit in there  as well. Pretty stellar

growler offering from notes. pours a golden orange/ yellow hazy color and gives way to a clean white head that holds for a bit. Smell is rich with citrusy floral hops candy like malt. Tate is rich with citrus hop components, orange lemon peach. malt sweetness comes through but is cleaned up by a decent bitter finish. Mouthfeel is full body and rich. low carbonation and smooth. Overall a very enjoyable DIPA

Swing top bottle provided by maltzilla.  Clear yellow pour with a white head.  Fruity/citrusy hop aromas.  Really tasty with pleasant citrusy hop flavors supported by a sturdy caramel malt backbone...

Hook up thanks to Toby. Pours a surprisingly cloudy orange color with lots of particulates floating around. A small white head. The nose is very interesting; raw, earthy bursts of citrus and simcoe, some herbal tea notes, pine. The flavor is unconventional in some ways, and considering the number of India Pale Ales, that is difficult. A smooth rich citrus flavor, very light bitterness initially, orange peel, some resin, lemons. Finishes very smooth with lingering bitterness just like an orange peel. This beer is only lacking a robust palate which certainly could be from the transportation to Utah. It has a earthy unique flavor which is simple and yet awesome. I guess Im officially in on Hill Farmstead. This reminds me more of a single IPA; it isnt overly done in any sense. Lovely. On tap this could be a very high rating- some day Vermont!

An absolutely glowing example of fragrance, sparkle, and substance coming together under the umbrella of fresh hop flavor; orchard like aromas of citrus and stone fruits, cannabis, and flowers lead to flavors thankfully quite the same.

Uninterrupted by elements of balance and entirely not needing them.  Crisp and clean in the mouth, lingering in hop oils and leafy dryness, with no trace of sugar or heat; this is a high standard.

750ml growler from Glouglouburp.  Pours a cloudy amber with an off-white head.  Nose is of citrus and pine.  Taste is of citrus and pine with a nice caramel malt balance.  Very tasty.  Mouthfeel is medium and bitter, yet smooth.
Hazy orange pour with a soapy white head.  Aroma of pine, citrus, and hint of caramel.  Lots of pine and hop flavor with some citrus and caramel background.  Really nice!

Tap @ The Farmhouse.... hazy light amber pour , one finger white head , excellent lace . Aroma of citrus ( peach , grapefruit ) hops . Solid upfront bitterness ,excellent hop flavor , sweet malt middle and a dry lasting enjoyable bitter finish .  Medium body and carbonation . Awesome .

Growler, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks Dany!), split with Matts_Property, pours opaque orange with a white head. Aroma of rich resinous and piney hops, augmented with loads of tropical fruits (mango and peach), and a big caramel malt backing. Flavour is extremely piney and resinous hops, with tropical fruits and a wonderfully rich, dry hoppy / bitter hops finish. So much depth in the palate, and the dry piney hops linger on and on. This is an amazing one.

Growler split with mcberko. pours translucent orange with a small white head. Aroma of piney hops, floral notes, citrus and caramel malts. Flavour is largely of piney hops, tropical fruits, with a well balanced caramel malt background. Dry, hoppy bitter after taste. So good!

Lightly murky golden amber with small white head, some lacing, little retention... lots of citrus and pine in the nose... Piney, some citrus flavors, not very bitter, doesnt feel like 8.2... I really like this brewery, they dont seem to go over the top with ABV and huge malt bills...  I like how the ipas tend to be nicely hoppy without the sweet malts in behind while not be especially bitter, simple but likely horribly complex to brew... dry medium bodied, somewhat likely, though i found the flavors to be a little muddled in this particular beer...

On Tap at the Black Back in Waterbury VT.
Pours a cloudy lemony amber color with a thinnish white head that seems to dissipate quickly. Smells like hops, no really it does :) Earthy spicy hops abound with that spicy oniony flair to them. Little if any malt evident in the aroma, but Im sure they did indeed use some malts in this beer. Taste is Bitter pine and earthy. Hints of caramel malt are there for a nano second but this one is all about the hops. Finishes rather dry with a long lingering spicy bitterness. Moderate carbonation, medium thin body with a resinous tart mouthfeel. I enjoyed this one, but it wasnt my favorite of the night. One curiosity is that all of the Hill beers I had were very cloudy, not sure if that is the way they are supposed to be or if we had trouble pouring.
Okay, its great.  Creamy...a really fantastic mouthfeel.  Citrus and floral hops, fruity sweetness, nice bitterness.  A must try on tap of you get the chance.
Growler.  Pours orange tan head.  Nose is bitter hopped, tase is grassy hopped.  Ok.

Growler shared at Seans 30th Birthday. Woot. Pours a murky glowing yellow gold hue, touches of deeper orange in the middle, well hazed, with a good healthy whitish head atop that dies to a film, laces ok. Aromas are a deeper citrus element, lots of lemon and grass, florals and touches of grapefruit. A good healthy earthy bitterness pairs with citrusy hops. Some touches of sweeter malts, but largely a hop dominant nose. Initial is lighter end of medium bodied throwing a healthy bitter lemon, lemon peel, and grass, and florals. A nice bready malts, some touches of sweeter toffee. But really light in body, soapy and and evervescent. Really nice. A solid beer, not as good as Double Citra in my book. Very nice.

Draft at Eulogy.

Pours a very dark, hazy and completely opaque golden orange color with dark tangerine/orange hues and a one finger frothy white head.  Decent retention slowly fading into a thick lasting cap.  Sporadic streaks, rings and chunk of soapy lacing.  

Slightly earthy aroma with dank resinous hops and lots of earthy pine balanced by sweet citrus/tropical fruit and pale malt.  Lots of grapefruit in the nose with mango, orange peel and tangerine.  Pale malt underneath with hints of biscuit and graham cracker but this thing is bursting with tropical/citrus fruit.

Medim bodied with a blast of dry, dank, earthy hops up front with hints of pine and dry bitterness balanced by a sweet tropical/ citrus fruit presence.  Fuller bodied than expected and slightly creamy with hints of papaya ,lots of grapefruit and orange peel as well as some mango.  Dry, dank earthy hop presence balanced by the citrus.  Really dry and bitter at first but as the glass warms it becomes extremely well balanced with a ton of citrus and tropical fruit notes.

On tap at Isaac Newtons. Cloud and orange, a ring of head but quick to lace. Floral citrus and then pine aroma. Bitterness over the top, but sweetness does follow eventually. Full of flavor and a nice journey, which really is what I ask of a double IPA. For me, matches up well with PtE. Very tasty.
on tap @Capones RBSG-pours an off white head with trailing lace and cloudy orange color.  Aroma is pine/citrus.  Taste is pine/resin/citrus/grapefruit, secondary light malt.
hazy orange-gold, lightly oily top with almost no head. Cheesy flavor with heavy pine, oily finish, light husk and grain with a bit perfume finish and sweetness to steal its grace.

This poured a cloudy orangish yellowish color with a fluffy white head. Aroma was just filled with fresh cut citrus and pine hops, very resinous and dank too. Flavor is just straight hop juice, I love these fresh IPAs with dextrose, no malt to stand in the way at all, very complex between the different ypes of hops as well.
Hazed orange porue with creamy white head and lace, Sweet caramel, orange zest aroma. Sweet malt, orange zest, and a very nice citrus bitter finish. Medium bodied with good carbonation.

Golden orange with a white head.  Citrus and floral hops in the nose with a bit of sweetness, too.  Flavor has plenty of bright fruit, light floral notes, a bit of pine- though restrained- and nice sugary sweetness to round it out.  Finishes with a nice lingering hop bite.  (Draught at Monks)

Hazy yellow-orange pour with a thin but dense looking white head that retained very well. Aroma is fresh lemon zest, caramel, and citrus hops. Flavor is slightly sweet at first, and fruity. Somewhat tropical, with notes of mango and peach. Definite hop bitterness, with a strong citrus kick. Wonderfully balanced. Mouthfeel is perfect, not heavy but not light. Overwhelmingly good. I find it very comparable to Pliny the Elder.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2015 Draft at Hawthornes with Dallas, Jesse, Andrew and Elizabeth. Pours a hazy orange body with white lacing. Aroma is fresh, fresh citrus, grapefruit, lemon. Mouthfeel is fresh with notes of fresh pine, citrus, and grapefruit. Another great offering by the Hill.  incredible.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2012 Draft at Hawthornes: 750ml swing top bottle shared by sloth...Nice beer! Great pour... golden hazy orange color,  with a small head. Kick ass nose, citrus, mango, peachey.... Taste is a well balanced DIPA, that drinks easy as an IPA.. Taste is tropical fruits, slightly bitter. Mango, peach, juicey..... citrus with some pine tree notes. The juicey-est beer i have had.  Medium body, soft carbonation. Very easy to drink. I like that it is unfiltered, dry hopped 2x and naturally carbonated.... Overall: Great beer
On tap at hawthornes.  Chill bro chill.  Not as good as double Citra but good overall.

On tap at Capones.  Hazy orange with a trace of white foam.  Nose is citrus, honey, grass, mango and pineapple.  Resiny medium body with tongue tickling carb.  Taste is orange-grapefruit, pine and lemon peel.  A bit more depth and balance than the Double Citra.
Aroma of sweet grapefruit.  Pours blonde and hazy with a big fluffy head.  Tastes of pure cascade.  So yummy and fruity.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2012 On tap @ HF anniversary. Hazy orangey gold pour with white head. Juicy hop aroma, very potent aromas of centennial along with a whole variety of other stuff I imagine. Taste is hoppy, with a light honey twist. Very refreshing palate, dry but not abusively so. EVery good IIPA

On Tap at Hill Farmstead 1st Ann.
Hazy copper with a fluffy white head.  Aroma is a blast of fruity sweet hops, cool citrus and piney bitterness. Crisp and refreshing, the flavor is playful citrus, grapefruit, bitter pine tree, Fresh, Sweet, and crisp.  Another home run.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2012 On tap at Hill Farmsteads first anniversary celebration. Hazy copper pour with a massive white frothy head. The aroma holds dank resin, nectar fruits, pineapple, evergreen, and citrus. The flavor is a beautiful mix of citrus incarnations with epic evergreen resin.. Perfect balance with a perfect body and perfect  caressing carbonation.  
After having a keg of this on my kegerator, I must up my rating. It never ceases to amaze me.
On draft at the brewery.  Pours a cloudy golden orange with a medium sized off white head.  Aroma of fresh citrus, pine and bitter hops.  Taste is much the same as the aroma.

Draft.  Pours a golden body with a white head, good retention, and even better lacing.  Big hoppy fruit tones all over this guy.  Citrus, pineapples, and grapefruit notes.  Nice bitter hop tones laced with quite a bit of pine and hop resins.  Nugget and a hint of herbal and grass tones.  Really excellent, Its an A bomb from Abner.  Some body fan me, im starstruck by this dude.
Draft @ Blind Tiger. Golden orange pour with some white head. Pine, citrus, pineapple aromas. Flavor is pine, herbal and light tropical citrus tones, nice IPA.

On tap at Hill Farmstead on November 4, 2010. Served in a Hill Farmstead wine glass. Thanks to Shaun for his incredible generosity for spending a good deal of time with us.

Pours a nice orange color with a bit of copper overtones. White head and some lacing. The nose is really nice with a good dose of citrus, orange, and some light pine. A touch of light grain in the background.

The flavor is nice with orange juice and a bit of rind. Some very light grapefruit as well. A touch of pine and spruce in the finish, which is nice and dry. Good carbonation levels and a nice bitterness. A really tasty brew. Thanks again, Shaun.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 11-14-2010

Hill farmstead abner. Growler fill from Shaun. Big thanks... Pours a  
hazy, somewhat muddled, medium apricot orange pour with a thin to  
medium white head head that quickly dispersed leaving a thin ring  
around the edges... Pungent and juicy west coast style nose with big- 
on tropical hop assertiveness tangerine and red grapefruit, albeit  
somewhat sweet. Tremendously aromatic with a perfect amalgamation of  
hop varietals... Flavors are sompletely there as well and stay true  
from what was presented by the aroma. Trying not to be redundant, the  
hop profile really shines while providing a nice degree of sweetness  
through the middle while culminating with a nice hop resiny, almost  
citrus rind finish. Body provides all there needs to be as well as  
such goes for the level of carbonation. Cant say that this is on the  
level as ephraim nor is/was it aimed to be but this holds its own in  
the most completest of senses.
9/4/8/4/16
UPDATED: NOV 15, 2014 Growler at Paul and Ryans tasting. Pours clear gold. White head. Nose and taste of apple, caramel malt, citrus, pineapple and spruce. Tasty.

Drank from a growler provided by Sean into a perfect pint glass... The body is an ugly murky medium honey gold with a hint of orange. A tope head without much retention or lacing, weird looking... The aroma is light dank hops and pine with some herbal notes. A little boring, not a ton going on... The taste is better with more citrus notes coming through. The hops are pine and bitter, balanced... The mouthfeel is really nice, good heft and carbonation.... Easy to drink.

This is an above average dipa, Id have again on tap.

Growler at the 5,000 party. Poured a very good looking, especially from a growler that was transported hundreds of miles, hazy orange/amber body with a smaller white frothy head. Aroma is loaded with tons of citrus and grapefruit plus a slight touch of cat piss. Flavor follows suit of the aroma. Medium bodied with average carboantion, the aftertaste was only on the mildly bitter side and could have used a slight boost for a DIPA. Overall fantastic.

Either a bottle or growler shared at Paul and Ryans 5,000th rate tasting. Pours bright gold with a white head. Big fresh bright citric aroma with piney and fresh floral notes as well. The flavor is hop forward with just the perfect amount of malty balance. Fresh citric and floral hops. Ridiculously good. A bottle of Pliny the Elder was opened a bit before this, and I though Abner way better. Awesome.

From tap at the brewery. Pours hazy orange with a small, white and slight rocky head. Aroma is dense fruity, peachy and grapefruity hoppy. Smooth, fruity, peachy and grapefruity. Bitter. Bone dry, clean and crisp citrusy hoppy. Nice dry and yet lingering fruity finish.

WOW, what a fn beer. On Tap, hazy orange pour, off white head with tiny little bubbles. Aroma is sick...juicy peach, ripe grapefruit, very slight pine. This beer smells and tastes like Pliny the Elder but is better! Taste is caramel, oak, sour diesel funk. Hop bitterness only comes on just as you finish a sip. Spotty rings of lacing left behind on glass. Leaves an almost juicy fruit aftertaste in mouth. Excellent Imperial IPA. Does Hill Farmstead make a bad beer?

A: The beer pours a cloudy orange color with a couple of fingers of cream colored head. Awesome sticky lacing to go with it.

S: Smells like fresh grapefruit and tons of pine. Theres a slight woodiness to it, like rosemary, and a fair amount of grass. There is a bit of bread to the nose, but otherwise its all hops.

T: Tastes like grapefruit too. Really fresh, vibrant, and juicy citrus flavor and a moderate pine bitterness on the finish. There are some grassy notes again and maybe a bit of a floral quality. A touch of bread to go with it all.

M: The body is medium with a moderate carbonation. Probably could be a bit higher, but thats what happens when you ship a growler from one corner of the country to another.

D: Hopefully all of the Hill Farmstead IPAs are similarly well done. Even with the alcohol content where it is, this is a dangerously easy to drink beer.

Verre de dégustation, provenant dun fût, dégusté au Winter Beer Gathering 2011 chez Hill Farmstead Brewery (Greensboro, VT). Arôme: Odeur de zestes dorange et de pamplemousse. Apparence: La couleur est blonde voilée. Saveur: Goût dagrumes avec une pointe dhoublons résineux et de melon miel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût houblonné. (Rating #3525)

Deep golden orange pour.  The nose has a bright mix of soft spiciness along with a bit of black pepper, fruity/zesty citrus peel and lots of orange and grapefruit.  A little bit of soft fruit.  Lean malt and some lemon.  Assertive bitterness and some nice fruitiness.  Fresh, chewy and tasty IIPA.

growler, thanks to kan for sharing. this pours hazed orange with foamy white head. nose has powdery, resiny hop flowers with juicy citrus notes. flavors have a nice big resiny hop pellets, citrus tropical fruit, and melon.  medium bodied, nice aroma but flavor is too one dimensional.

Draft from Capones via 1L hand bottle.  Thanks, Matt!  You rule!  Pour is turbid orangy with off-white head.  Nose is just lovely; a medley of tropical fruit, including honeydew, mango, tangerine, canteloupe, peppery notes, and big hops.  Tastes very hoppy, extremely fruity, with tons of layered tropical fruit complexity.  i got no less than honeydew, canteloupe, mango, star fruit, kiwi, tangerine, and pineapple in this.  Smooth finish, awesome complexity, and just a beauty of a beer to behold, brother!

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2012 My Bottom Line:
Citrusy, floral hops and lean straw-like cereals evolve in a soft mouthfeel, leading to levelled piney bitterness for a paradoxically easygoing, intense Double IPA.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A creamy veil of foam laces around the hazy blond.
-Every ingredient is expressed clearly and harmoniously. This is very drinkable too for a Double IPA, especially if you compare it to Lawsons (excellent) Double Sunshine and Hopzilla, which are brasher in the finish.
-The soft, natural carbonation and svelte mouthfeel make for optimal drinkability, which is very dangerous at this abv!
-Shaun is one of those brewers which make you realize how disappointing most brewers can be. Plain evil, I say. ;)

On tap at Hill Farmstead and from many growlers.

Draught at Capones:  Aroma of hops, light citrus, light Earth, slight grass, slight orange, and a hint of pine.  Poured yellow/gold in color with a huge, creamy, dense, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Not sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is medium to heavily bitter and medium sweet.  Tastes of malt, hops, wood, pine, resin, slight orange, light citrus, marijuana, light grass, and evergreen.  Medium body.  Slick, then dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Hops, pine, citrus, light resin, finish is medium to heavily bitter and lightly sweet, as well as dry.  8.2%ABV is completely hidden throughout.

Pours a hazy orange with a fluffy white head that lingers at about two fingers for quite a while out of the growler. It laces beautifully down the glass through the entire session.

Aroma is citrus and a hint of resin. Its a bright aroma, but not sharp. Not overbearing, but assertive.

Taste is a nice balance of citrusy hops and malt backbone with a bit of hop oil that lends a good mouthfeel. it ultimately finishes a little dry and tart with a tail end of the hop bitterness. 

Overall, a very drinkable, tasty IIPA.

Sampled from the tap at the brewery. Poured a hazy gold with an orange hue and an off-white head that lasted throughout the beer. Aroma had a nice combination of citrus and pine notes with a hint of backing hay. Flavor began with citrus and was joined by a more subtle pine note with a backing of grain and hay.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 In short: A vibrant fruity and floral hop bomb.  Great IIPA.
How: Tap at the brewery
The look: Partly cloudy shining golden body topped by a large off-white head with good retention a leaving plenty of lacings.  Perfect look.
In long: Nose is vibrant with fruity hops (tropical fruits) and a strong floral character.  Taste is mostly about the hops.  The malt backbone is solid enough to support this hop monster but the crisp toasted bready malts with a bit of caramel play second violin to the hops.  Assertive hopping that is both refreshing (tropical fruits), floral and with a resinous edge that takes the bitterness level to the medium-high range.  Long sticky hops resin after-taste.  This beer was described by the brewer as an Imperial Edward (their basic APA).  As much as I like Abner, and IT IS excellent, I still slightly prefer the highly sessionnable Edward.  Another great brew from Hill Farmstead.  I now believe that Hill Farmstead is the greatest thing since sandwiches (which as we all know is the greatest thing since sliced bread)

Tap at Blind Tiger. Poured a beautiful rich gold amber. Nose is piny and grapefruit hops. The flavor follows the nose but thats an understatement. This beer has great hop flavors but is so well balanced with a fantastically delicious malt base. Finish is bitter but by no means overpowering. Really really good beer

On tap at the brewery - Poured a slightly cloudy orangish amber in color with a medium whitish head that produced plenty of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is thick with hops... citrus/grapefruit and pine resin.  Flavor is quite hoppy, but not overwhelming at all.  Some malts in the background to even it out.  Artfully made... a really good DIPA.

Growler that I shared at a recent tasting. Amazing beer, I am a huge hophead and this really did impress me for sure. Lovely citrus aroma crawls from my glass, paired with that wonderful carmel color makes it a very tempting beer. Lovely hop profile makes the bitterness very welcoming, mouthfeel is very good, only wish I had a keg of this stuff.

Growler shared by JW77. Pours hazy orangish color with off white head. Aromas of grapefriuit and citrus. Citrusy flavor with some pine and caramel. Medium body with average carbonation and a slightly resinous mouthfeel. A nice DIPA. Thanks Jonathan.

I am not a Big IPA or Double IPA fan, not my style at all.  That said, this is simply amazing beer.,  The most sessionable, refreshing big IPA I have ever had.  LIke his regular strength IPAs, this beer is a flawless beer.  If more brewers took chances in the brewing process they might be able to achieve a beer like this instead of throwing a bunch of junk in the pot and saying wow look at our double mumbo jumbo bad ass triple hoppy blah blah blah IPA.  Shaun Hill is cranking out beer that is totally unhooked.  The guy is competing with himself right now.  People whine about the price.  They should drink something else if they arent willing to pay an extra buck for something outstanding that doesnt match their expectations of what lazy brewers have set as the standard American Double IPA.

Growler shared by ygtbsm94 on 6/6/10: Pours a transparent bright bronze with a spotty-lacing off-white head.  Has a fresh resiny grapefruity hoppy nose with some sweet pale malty undertones.  Starts with good fullness and rich sweet caramel malty nose with a resiny grapefruity hoppy flavor and bitter balance toward a drier bittersweet finish.  A pretty nice double IPA.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2010 Re-rate 101020. ­On tap at Brewery.
Appearance : Hazy yellow with a creamy head. Lots of lacing.

Aroma : Intense fruity and leafy hops. Nice mangos and passion fruits. Fresh apricots/peaches. 

Taste : Fruity and leafy with notes of mangos and a bit of white sugar. Intense hops. Finish is a bit warm with intense hops. A tiny bit mineral also.

Overall : This has nothing to do with the one I had at Farmhouse (see rating below). Nose is very intense with awesome fruity notes. Taste has intense green and leafy hops. Very fresh. Rather drinkable even if a tiny bit hot on the finish. Another great beer from Shaun that Im glad I could re-rate !


On tap at Farmhouse Tap and Grill.
Appearance : Nice clear amber with no head.

Aroma : Very VERY peachy, very fruity with lots of mangos.

Taste : Fruity peaches and mangos. Quite hoppy but not very bitter. Palate is dead flat.

Overall : Nice fruits (a bit too much maybe) but carbonation is way too soft. Looks like my glass stayed in the fridge all night. Rather unidimensional, fruits and not much else. I think the beer had something wrong, Id be glad to give it another chance...

Nice full body once its poured with a fluffy head. Aroma is sweet, hoppy, rich, caramel, juicy hops and resin. Flavor is big, juicy, some caramel and rich full malt body with lots of hops. Citrus and pine hops but not overly bitter. Alcohol seems to be well hidden too.

Thanks to weearenot3.6 for sharing.  Pours a lightly hazy golden orange with a medium bubbly creamy white head.  Aroma of pine resin, orange, tea and light caramel.  Flavor was very resiny, grapefruit, pine, tea, nice and dry, bitterness was there but so smooth.  I would have called this one Lebron though.
UPDATED: OCT 9, 2011 Poured a medium and clear amber color with a smaller sized head. Aromas of floral hops, skunky weed, and some lighter fruitiness. Tastes of floral, citrus, and some caramel.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2011 Draft, RBSG 2011 bus tour.  Small off-white head, cloudy amber.  Aroma is moderately sweet, kiwi.  Taste is moderately sweet, grapefruit, pineapple.  Medium body, light acidity.  9/3/7/4/15

Shenandoah Throwdown 2010, growler, thanks peregrinari.  Medium off-white head atop hazy amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, orange, some pine, grapefruit.  Taste is moderately sweet, orange, some grapefruit, resin, light alcohol.  Medium-full body, resinous. 8/4/7/3/14

Shenandoah Throwdown, growler, thanks peregrinari.   Another delicious one from Hillstead.  I found this one to be a little sweeter and heavier than the citra, but still very well made and delicious.  Alcohol well hidden.  Very tasty, Id love to try it on cask.

Orange-brown pour with a thin white head.  Lots of piny herbal hops on the nose.  Good balanced dry pine flavor with strong malt notes.  Herbal hops with notes of pine and grapefruit.  Very bitter.  Excellent IPA.

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2011 On tap at Farmhouse Tap and Grill in Burlington. Hazy copper pour, 1 finger semi-dense white head. Aroma is absolutely packed with pine and spruce notes, with citrus, floral, and dank grass notes forming a strong background- even from the nose, one can tell this is an absolute resin bomb. Flavor is similar, though the citric sweetness comes out a bit more prominently to balance the heavy bitterness beautifully. Palate is awesome; incredibly crisp and drinkable for an 8.2 percent DIPA that is super dank. Still has that big body, but glides down so smoothly. The mouthfeel puts this beer in the top echelon for the style. Awesome.

Plenty of citrus, pine, herbal and floral hop character in the nose along with deep malt sweetness.  Beautifully clear, dark orange-golden body is topped by a decent white head that lasts well and sticks to the sides of the glass.  Strong bitterness hits the tongue first with a follow through of very sweet malts chased by grapefruit, orange, floral and pinelike hop flavours in succession.  Medium full body with moderate to strong carbonation that keeps it from becoming too sticky.  Sampled on tap at the brewery.

The bitterness is the star here and theres enough light sweetness to keep it from being overpowering.

Dank, pot nose, really fresh herb, very light citrus, just a touch of honey. The taste is nicely dry for an IIPA, just a touch of honey and cotton candy, lots of citrus peal, tangerine, dankness. Very nice.

Pouring at the opening of Hill Farmstead.  Had this both on draught and cask and while the draught was good, the cask was just phenomal and I went back to it 4 or 5 times once it was tapped.  Just great stuff.  Pours a nice clear amber on draft, and a little more haze on the cask version, big creamy white head.  Large pine and soft citrus, which on cask is just blown away by the dripping passion fruit and piles of tropical fruit.  Medium bodied, smooth malt.  Cask picks up a light sweetness with some pineapple tones.  Smooth long grapefruit finish.

This one will put you in another world.
